channel.title: Master Feed (Updated every 30 mins)
channel.description: Master Feed (Updated every 30 mins) generated by script

item.title: Yemen’s generation without classrooms
item.description: A decade of war and humanitarian crisis has cratered Yemen’s education system for girls.

item.title: What Bill Gates Overlooks About Climate Change
item.description: Bill Gates recently argued that we should de-emphasize the existential threat posed by climate change in order to “put human welfare at the center of our climate strategies.” But how tolerant should we be of the risk of creating a climate that will be disastrous for human welfare for centuries to come?

item.title: The AI Labor Shock Is Coming for Women
item.description: Women comprise the majority of workers in more than half of the 40 occupations that are most at risk of displacement by AI. In the near term, political and business leaders can prevent female workers from becoming collateral damage by ensuring that they are offered equal opportunities for access and upskilling.

item.title: Syria joins the American-led fight against Islamic State
item.description: But some in Ahmed al-Sharaa’s ranks still sympathise with the jihadists

item.title: The Nostalgic Delusion of 1989
item.description: The U.S. military buildup around Venezuela has drawn comparisons to past regime change in Panama. But Washington cannot invade its way to democracy in Caracas.

item.title: This Is the Future of U.S. Foreign Aid Under Trump
item.description: Post-USAID assistance may depend on a country’s strategic value to Washington.

item.title: A New Economic Playbook for Policymakers
item.description: The Washington Consensus assumed that economic growth would automatically follow market liberalization. That belief has not aged well, and a new policy approach must include innovation, good jobs, climate stability, gender equality, and a state empowered to provide effective regulation and high-quality public services.

item.title: The War Room newsletter: Nuremberg 80 years on, a reckoning
item.description: Rosie Blau, co-host of “The Intelligence”, examines post-war accountability and retribution

item.title: COP30 Must Do Good, Not Just Avoid Harm
item.description: As the host of this year's UN Climate Change Conference, Brazil seeks to make COP30 the “COP of implementation.” Translating commitments into robust action should include providing indigenous peoples with direct access to predictable and sustainable finance, and treating them as equal partners, rather than as beneficiaries.

item.title: The Future of International Aid
item.description: Even without US funding cuts, there would be a need for fresh thinking about how the aid sector works. Financial resources and other programs are not being delivered as efficiently as they could be to do the greatest good for the greatest number of people who are most in need.

item.title: Will AI Democratize Access to Equity Financing?
item.description: A century of credit-driven growth has left most economies dependent on banks that fund only the safest bets. By lowering the costs of disclosure, due diligence, and compliance, AI could open equity markets to the smaller, riskier firms that drive innovation and job creation, unlocking a new engine of sustainable growth.

item.title: With Approval Soaring, How Ambitious Can Japan’s New Prime Minister Be?

item.title: Why Emerging Economies Are Embracing AI
item.description: Surveys show that emerging economies’ populations are not only well aware of the opportunities AI creates, but also more optimistic about the technology than advanced-economy populations. They might not lead the way in building AI models, but they can use the technology to advance their economic- and social-development goals.

item.title: Mamdani’s Big Bet
